title: The Error Explorer
story: How do we measure how wrong our predictions are? Mean Squared Error (MSE) is the most common loss function for regression. It calculates the average of squared differences between predictions and actual values. Lower MSE means better model!
instructions: Import numpy as np. Create `y_true` with [10, 20, 30, 40] and `y_pred` with [12, 18, 32, 38]. Calculate `errors` (difference), `squared_errors` (errors squared), and `mse` (mean of squared errors). Print mse.
solutionHidden:
import numpy as np
y_true = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])
y_pred = np.array([12, 18, 32, 38])
errors = y_true - y_pred
squared_errors = errors ** 2
mse = squared_errors.mean()
print(mse)

hints.text: Subtract arrays to get errors, square with **2, then use .mean() for average
